Harvey Milk.Action: Tries to break tension with a joke during a mostly straight or hostile audience speech.
Uses humor to connect with a skeptical union crowd, making them laugh.
Strategically uses humor to break tension with a tough audience, adapting his speech to audience type.
Persists in recruiting and engaging a hostile mob with a bullhorn, showing leadership and confidence.
Wears a plain, ill-fitting suit during a campaign speech but still manages to get a laugh from a skeptical audience.
Acknowledges that as a gay activist he becomes a target of insecure and disturbed people, showing self-awareness and tolerance.
Attempts to make friendly eye contact and initiates a casual conversation with Scott Smith, sharing personal information like his birthday openly.
Jokes self-deprecatingly about working for a big, evil corporation to connect with Scott.
Records a will recognizing the danger he faces, showing foresight.
Pauses and is unsure what to say during recorded will, indicating some hesitation.
Attempts to engage Scott Smith with introduction and small talk, showing social initiative.
Jokes about corporate establishment and handles teasing about bad breath by covering mouth, showing adaptability and humor.
Plays humorously with Scott, showing a lighthearted and friendly side.
Feeds Scott spoonfuls of cream pie from a tray full of food, over the top and adorable gesture.
Warns Scott about the dangers of responding to strangers and offers protection and guidance.
Uses a playful nickname 'little Scottie-san' indicating affectionate familiarity.
Shows quick wit and playful intelligence by cleverly using his watch to prove his age eligibility.
Acts confidently and takes the initiative in a social/romantic interaction, demonstrating self-assurance.
Gives Scott safety advice about New York dangers, showing awareness and responsibility.
Offers to guide Scott through the city safely, indicating both knowledge and willingness to help.
Laughs off insult about becoming fat, engages playfully and tenderly with Scott by wiping pie from his hair and tackling him to kiss him.
Admits honestly that he is afraid of losing his job and feels he hasn't done anything he's proud of.
Suggests half-jokingly to run away together with Scott, showing openness and intimacy.
Acknowledges his fear of exposure and discretion regarding people who know about his sexuality to protect his job.
Admits honestly that at forty he hasn't done anything he's proud of.
Responds to Scott's teasing about his eating habits with humor and playfulness.
Expresses a half-serious idea of running away together, showing some openness but lacking concrete planning in this moment.
Snaps numerous photographs documenting the Castro neighborhood, observing and capturing details and faces, indicating attentiveness and intention to understand the environment.
Pointing out the new overt expressions of gay identity (two hippie boys walking with arm around each other) with interest and excitement, showing observational skills and cultural awareness.
Commenting pointedly to Scott Smith about his spending of the last unemployment check, challenging him to do something useful, reflecting practical thinking and a sense of responsibility.
Initiates opening a small business with low overhead, showing practical planning and resourcefulness.
Welcomes a wary neighbor (McConnelly) warmly and attempts to integrate into the local business community by asking to join the Merchant's Association, demonstrating social and strategic skills.
Encourages Scott Smith to stay and work with him instead of settling for waitressing, showing confidence in his own plan and in his partner.
Tries to keep the conversation friendly despite McConnelly's hostility.
Grabs Scott's hand to keep him from reacting angrily to discrimination.
Energetically plans to form a supportive business association to revitalize the neighborhood and listen to customers' needs.
Keeps Scott from reacting angrily during confrontation with McConnelly, recognizing the strategic timing.
Responds energetically and quickly to hostility by forming a plan to create a gay-owned business association and revitalize the neighborhood with targeted outreach and fundraising.
Uses friendly tone initially when confronted with hostility, attempting to defuse the situation.
Thanks McConnelly sarcastically as he walks away, possibly indicating a recognition of the difficult environment but remaining confident.
Prepares a home-cooked meal with candles and flowers for Scott.
Smashes a cream pie into Scott's face playfully and wishes him happy birthday.
Moves through the crowd shaking hands and thanking people for joining the Castro Village Association.
Politely asks the shop owner about business and shows interest in his situation.
Jokes with McConnelly and diffuses tension while promoting gay-friendly business, showing social skill and confidence.
Kissing Scott openly in public as a deliberate, bold show of identity and charisma.
Creates a welcoming environment in the Camera Shop, attracting activists and fostering community.
Not directly managing the Camera Shop himself, relying on Danny Niccoletta to run it, acknowledging own lack of interest.
Laughs warmly with Danny after his playful imitation of opera diva gestures.
Welcomes Allan Baird warmly and introduces him respectfully to others.
Eases Allan Baird's nerves by pulling him aside and engaging him in a private conversation, showing emotional intelligence and tact.
Confidently proposes a strategic alliance to get Coors beer out of every bar in the Castro by the end of the week, showing goal-oriented thinking and negotiation skill.
Acknowledges that his official status as 'Mayor of the Castro' is not yet established, displaying honesty while maintaining a confident public image.
Mentions an idealistic idea about gathering an army of queers to secede, but quickly recognizes current movement limitations, showing realistic assessment.
Claims to have friends in very low places and influence within the community, indicating networking and social capital.
Shows no evidence of failure to understand Allan Baird’s situation or the difficulty of unionizing, and instead offers constructive partnership.
Organizes a successful boycott of Coors in gay bars, uniting community and unions to gain power.
Takes leadership role in protecting community from police harassment by quickly responding to threats.
Gently cleans Scott's head wound after police brutality.
Encourages making a political statement to be seen and heard, showing empathy for marginalized groups.
Playfully kisses Scott and shares light moments despite serious circumstances.
Waves, shakes hands, flirts warmly with many people on the street, displaying friendliness.
Sets his box down beside a police officer, indicating confidence or possible lack of fear but no hostility.
Approaches a young, disinterested person to engage in political conversation and attempts to recruit him to register to vote despite initial rejection.
Shows flexibility and persistence in conversation, adjusting his approach to understand Cleve’s background and concerns.
Acknowledges Cleve's skepticism and discomfort, tries to connect it to wider social change instead of pushing direct recruitment.
Engages in friendly banter but risks seeming out of touch or overly eager by addressing Cleve as 'kid' and 'old man' and pushing quickly to register.
Does not insist or get confrontational when rejected, instead shifts to encouragement and motivational remarks, showing emotional and social skill.
Acknowledges the victim Robert Hillsborough was his customer and defends the victim's partner Jerry as a lover rather than a 'trick.'
Expresses cynicism about authorities' willingness to protect the gay community, saying there would be more witnesses if police cared.
Identifies the victim as a customer and challenges the cop’s terminology about the victim's relationship, showing knowledge and confidence in advocating for truth and respect.
Points out the lack of witnesses willing to identify attackers due to police failure to protect the community, indicating awareness of social dynamics and systemic problems.
Encourages discretion among his community to avoid trouble on streets.
Shows friendly and sincere behavior by complimenting a customer's boyfriend.
Challenges the legitimacy of so-called 'gay leaders' and questions their appointment, implying skepticism toward others' authority.
Questions why his campaign manager isn't leading the meeting, displaying oversight and attention to roles.
Engages directly with political strategy and questions the setup of endorsements and leaders, showing political awareness.
Casually interacts with customers and observes details (commenting on photos and boyfriend), demonstrating social ease and observation skills.
No apparent indication of poor competence or failure in this excerpt.
Dismisses a threatening hate letter with humor and sticks the drawing on the refrigerator to confront fear directly.
Shows skepticism towards established 'gay leaders' and challenges their authority while advocating for grassroots activism.
Wraps his arms around Scott to offer comfort despite the overwhelming odds.
Questions David Goodstein's strategy of endorsing straight candidates, showing skepticism towards discreet, less confrontational approaches.
Seeks endorsement from a magazine to support his candidacy, showing openness and collaboration.
Challenges the notion that a gay candidate is bad for the community's image, advocating for dignity and respect.
Acknowledges police brutality and community neglect, expressing concern and solidarity with the community.
States that there are no real gay allies and that friends cannot fully understand the struggle, showing frustration and determination.
Insists on self-respect as necessary for demanding respect from others, promoting dignity and self-empowerment.
Insists on running for office despite advice that it's too early, showing confidence and willingness to challenge norms.
Points out the lack of true gay allies and the need for gay representatives in office, demonstrating clear political insight.
Engages in a dialogue about community issues, showing awareness of social and political challenges.
Asks David Goodstein why he hasn't run himself, using a rhetorical strategy to challenge reluctance in the community.
Expresses frustration that acceptance can't be demanded overnight, showing impatience that might be seen as lacking political prudence.
Refuses to go back into the closet, asserts self-respect and independence, not asking for acceptance.
Turns around ready for a fight after being criticized.
Rejects playing it safe or seeking approval, asserting he is part of a movement rather than merely a candidate.
Reacting defensively and ready for a fight when challenged, showing confidence and awareness of his purpose.
Fails to get elected, coming in 10th out of 32 candidates for 6 seats.
Decides to run again in 1975 with minor adjustments, demonstrating persistence and learning from past experience.
Pulls Scott close and kisses him after Scott criticizes his new look, showing affection and playfulness.
Talks openly about his transformation and standing up to social expectations despite criticism.
Uses humor and light teasing with Scott, indicating friendliness and warmth.
Speaks out strongly against discrimination and violence toward the LGBTQ community, highlighting social injustices sincerely.
Uses sharp language to criticize political machines as dehumanizing and unresponsive.
Engages Art Agnos with humor and friendly banter after a serious debate.
Stops and ponders Art's words, showing reflection and consideration.
Humorously engages with Scott about politics during dinner, then sincerely appreciates the meal with a warm smile.
About to intervene when Scott is chasing volunteers out, but keeps quiet as asked.
Focuses on political strategy and volunteers crowded in apartment, seemingly neglecting Scott's needs initially.
Ponders Art's words seriously, reflecting on the need to give people a reason for optimism.
Engages in an impromptu strategy meeting with his political entourage and volunteers, showing active campaign involvement.
Almost intervenes when Scott asks volunteers to leave the apartment but ultimately stays silent as instructed, demonstrating some self-control.
Shows warmth and appreciation when eating Scott's meal, displaying emotional intelligence and good interpersonal skills.
Does not have a car, which might indicate some lack of preparation or resources but is not explicitly a sign of incompetence here.
Gives a warm smile after a delicious meal.
Reassures Scott with a promise during a moment of uncertainty.
Comforts Cleve by inviting him inside and making coffee when he is upset.
Shares personal vulnerability and relates to Cleve’s feelings about relationships.
Offers encouraging and hopeful advice to Cleve about future relationships despite current pain.
Recognizes potential danger and tries to prepare by searching for a whistle or weapon when followed.
Keeps composure and takes Cleve inside and locks the door for safety.
Engages empathetically with Cleve, provides comfort and encouragement in a difficult moment.
Shows some vulnerability by admitting nervousness but still acts decisively.
Encourages Cleve Jones to fight for gay rights and not just cruise; shows sincerity about political struggle.
Admits 'winning isn't my strong suit,' showing vulnerability and honesty.
Laughs with Cleve Jones and warmly includes him in plans, building camaraderie.
Challenges Cleve Jones to assemble people quickly to support political efforts, demonstrating trust in him.
Focuses on the practicalities of political campaign (polls opening soon) without emotional distance, showing engagement.
Fake grins at Jim Rivaldo's attempt to cheer him up after a political loss, showing vulnerability and engagement.
Contemplates running for office a fourth time despite previous losses and expressed doubts, indicating persistence and dedication to community.
Does not openly display bitterness or resentment after loss to Anita Bryant, maintaining composure.
Considers running for office a fourth time despite previous losses, showing resilience and strategic thinking by focusing on a promising new district with strong support.
Expresses doubt about having another campaign in him, which may indicate self-doubt or hesitation.
Comforts a distressed caller who is suicidal, reassures him that there is nothing wrong with him, and offers support despite the caller being a stranger over the phone.
Responds immediately to a distressed caller contemplating suicide, provides calm reassurance and advice, listens attentively despite difficult circumstances.
Encourages a distressed boy on the phone to leave a harmful situation and assures him he will be welcomed and loved by others like him.
Maintains calm and offers reassurance to the boy even after learning he is in a wheelchair and unable to physically leave immediately.
Calmly tries to comfort and advise a distressed boy on the phone, despite the boy's difficult situation and eventual loss of contact.
Feeling overwhelmed and stunned after the distressing phone call and needing to be called by Dick to come down.
Asks policeman for permission to march the angry crowd, showing restraint and responsibility.
Acknowledges the anger of the crowd and articulates shared feelings, inviting them to follow him.
Admits uncertainty about where to lead the crowd but focuses on keeping them moving to prevent violence, showing sincerity and concern.
Leads a chanting march to channel the crowd's anger constructively, acting as a calming and unifying presence.
Pushes to control escalating anger to avoid riot and prevent harm to the community, demonstrating responsibility and trustworthiness.
Negotiates calmly with the policeman to lead the crowd, confidently asking for permission to march the angry crowd rather than letting the police control them.
Takes initiative by climbing onto a box to address the crowd with a bullhorn, showing command presence and leadership.
Leads a restless and angry crowd through the streets without a predetermined route, admitting 'I don't know' where they are going but focuses on keeping them moving to avoid riot.
Creates a marching chant to unify and direct the crowd’s energy, successfully bringing them together in a controlled way.
Attempts to manage rising tensions by planning to reroute crowd through Van Ness to Broadway, showing strategic thinking under pressure.
Addresses a hostile crowd with a message of hope and unity, encouraging fighting against discrimination and uplifting marginalized groups.
Speaks inclusively to diverse groups (young people suffering rejection, workers, minorities) expressing sincere concern for their struggles and offering hope.
Climbs the steps confidently, takes the bullhorn and delivers an inspiring speech that unites and energizes the crowd, positioning himself as a leader with a clear mission.
Uses specific examples and addresses diverse groups (young people in multiple locations, workers) showing skill in rhetorical strategy and audience awareness.
Acknowledges diversity and democratic empowerment of neighborhoods, emphasizing inclusion of minorities and the Castro community.
Describes Dan White's opposition using terms like 'social radicals, social deviants, and incorrigibles' but as spoken by Dan White, not Milk himself.
Prepares calmly and reflects in his apartment while listening to opera, showing personal depth and composure.
Explains the changes in voting rules clearly and strategically, showing understanding of political dynamics and the diversity of neighborhoods.
Prepares carefully for upcoming events (laid-out suit, Wagner music for focus), demonstrating planning and intentionality.
Expresses determination to protect the community from political threats by winning office.
Uses pressure on Scott to stay and support his campaign despite Scott's exhaustion.
Shows vulnerability and emotional pain when Scott leaves, indicating sensitivity and emotional openness.
Rants aggressively, tearing down campaign posters in frustration.
Recruits Anne Kronenberg as new campaign manager, recognizing the need for new blood and acknowledging her organizational skills.
Responds coolly to team skepticism about new campaign manager, maintains composure and control.
Directs team to gather intelligence on opponent's announcement timing.
Jokes with team to defuse tension and maintain morale.
Insists on including a woman to manage things, acknowledging her capability and courage.
Recognizes the need for diversity and management skills by appointing a capable woman as campaign manager, showing strategic thinking.
Hands out flyers to supporters despite exhaustion and raw throat near campaign end.
Pauses and looks pensively after receiving a 'Unite and Fight for Dan White' flier from a boy, attempts to pat the boy's head realizing he's gone.
Responds calmly and with humor when teammates joke about the newspaper endorsement and reactions of others.
Is actively involved in handing out flyers and campaign signs despite being exhausted and having a raw throat, showing dedication and endurance.
Pauses and focuses intently on a flier advocating for Dan White, indicating alertness and sensitivity to political threats.
Responds confidently and with a sense of humor to the newspaper endorsement, showing ease and self-assurance in dealing with publicity.
Smiles kindly at a drunk, vulnerable young man and brings a chair out for him to sit.
Watches Jack fall asleep/swoon drunk and gently stands over him like a protector.
Engages in affectionate physical intimacy with Jack, providing emotional and physical comfort without pressure or politics, creating a safe space.

Responds playfully and gently when Jack expresses love, showing affection and engagement.
Pulls Jack Lira inside the crowded party despite the shop being full, prioritizing him over others.
Turns away Rick Stokes and David Goodstein by telling them the place is too crowded and sorry.
Comforts Jack Lira, providing reassurance and a sense of safety.
Casts his vote carefully, showing awareness and participation in the democratic process.
Celebrates election victory confidently and manages the crowd, pulling Jack inside despite pressure from others.
Engages warmly with Jack Lira, uses friendly tone calling him 'darling' and asks if he likes the event
Answers TV interview emphasizing his role to open dialogue for sensitivities of all people and their problems
Engages confidently with the crowd and media, answers questions about his role thoughtfully, and shows awareness of political dynamics.
Does not follow up immediately on disruptive figures like Dan White, indicating a tacit postponement of confrontation.
Jokes about Anita Bryant's claim linking gays to drought, turning it into a hopeful moment that it is finally raining; cheers and camaraderie follow.
Acknowledges political necessity of cooperating with Dan White despite ideological differences, showing pragmatic tolerance.
Attempts to engage Dan White in personal conversation by asking about his time as a fireman, indicating friendliness and an effort to build rapport.
Engages Dan White in conversation, acknowledges firefighters' support, and offers collaboration, leading to a hesitant handshake.
Advises Cleve on appearance and behavior in City Hall to create a memorable, confident presence.
Gently educates Dan White, calls him uneducated but expresses willingness to teach him.
Invites Dan White to son's christening to build alliance, willing to attend despite differences.
Refers to Michael Wong as 'Lotus Blossom' in a familiar manner during strategy session.
Delegates tasks efficiently by assigning Cleve to handle mail and directing Anne to follow through.
Leads a strategic planning session focused on passing a citywide Gay Rights Ordinance with a unanimous vote, showing vision and political savvy.
Responds to critique by encouraging his team to improve the bill, showing openness to feedback and commitment to excellence.
Recognizes potential opposition from Dan White but sees him as an opportunity to educate and convert, demonstrating strategic thinking and confidence.
Agrees to attend Dan White's son's christening as a political move to gain an ally, showing political tact and ability to build relationships.
Greets proud constituents warmly as he heads home.
Avoids confrontation when Jack mentions the broken window and his difficult entry.
Engages positively with Jack, allowing a dance despite being busy and tired.
Notices the broken window and acknowledges the issue promptly.
Avoids confrontation with Jack about breaking in, focusing instead on responsibilities like the Town Hall meeting.
Quickly prepares to leave for work despite personal distractions, demonstrating focus and prioritization.
Does not address or secure the broken window immediately; delays repair.
Dances sweetly and intimately with Jack, showing tenderness and care.
Offers Jack a key to prevent property damage, demonstrating trust and goodwill.
Attends Dan's child's baptism despite feeling like an outsider, showing sincere support.
Proposes a citywide ordinance to protect employees from discrimination based on orientation, indicating concern and tolerance.
Engages Dan White in friendly conversation about his background, displaying openness and inclusiveness.
Agrees to watch out for each other's interests with Dan White despite political differences.
Attempts to lighten awkward situation with Mary Ann White with a joke, though it fails.
Shows reluctance to vote against Dan White's bill despite pressure from advisors.
Responds to Dan White's question about the Psychiatric Center cautiously by saying 'I'd have to study it...'
Acknowledges Dan White's campaign promise and suggests mutual cooperation by saying 'What do you say we watch out for each other's interests?'
Tries to break an awkward social moment with Mary Ann White by making a lighthearted comment, but it fails.
Shows reluctance to vote against Dan White despite pressure from advisors, indicating political calculation and understanding of alliances.
Defends Dan White despite skepticism from others, showing loyalty and trust.
Expresses empathy for Dan White's internal struggle and fear, recognizing shared experience.
Responds to Anne Kronenberg's bad news with optimism and excitement about the upcoming fight rather than fear.
Defends Dan White's political usefulness by citing voter registration numbers.
Expresses an insightful understanding of Dan White's internal struggle, reading fear and pressure in his eyes.
Quickly assesses and responds to political threats, asking pertinent questions about petition signatures and showing excitement about an impending political fight.
Uses humor and optimism to motivate his team in the face of a serious threat.
Participates in protest against John Briggs' anti-gay proposition, standing with community.
Addresses bigotry publicly on TV, referencing discrimination faced by Jews and Muslims to show solidarity.
Apologizes to Jack for being late and tries to comfort him, calling him 'sugar pea.'
Tells Jack, who is uncomfortable and locked in the coat room, 'Then go home.'
Does not stop to greet David Goodstein and others upon arrival, walking past them without acknowledgment.
Acknowledges being late and apologizes to Jack, showing awareness of social expectations and responsibility.
Responds firmly and clearly to Jack's complaints, attempting to manage the tense situation calmly.
Does not stop to greet David Goodstein and Rick Stokes, which could suggest single-minded focus or a brusque dismissal.

Critiques the Anti-Briggs Initiative flier for not explicitly mentioning gays and insists on clear representation of who is affected.
Calls the flier and the approach 'shit and masturbation' and a coward's response to a dangerous threat, expressing strong disagreement with the strategy.
Throws Phil Burton's flier into the fireplace and leaves the meeting after being asked to by David Goodstein and others.
Invites young people, women, fresh heads, fighters and organizers instead of politicians to join the cause.
Makes a lighthearted comment about paying the pizza guy, encouraging people to chip in.
Looks meaningfully at Scott Smith who just arrived with his boyfriend, indicating recognition and acceptance.
Selects young, fresh heads and organizers rather than politicians to build a movement.
Recognizes and values Scott as an asset despite others' reservations.
Takes control of the meeting to refocus efforts and keep momentum by addressing mundane issues like paying the pizza guy to maintain group morale.
Introduces the strategy of 'everybody's coming out' as a big new idea to broaden the movement and reach the majority.
Encourages everyone to come out of the closet openly and embrace their identity for political power and social change.
Insists that people who have not yet told their families, friends, or employers to do so immediately, despite concerns about privacy and safety.
Says 'If their families won't love them for who they are... then they should lose them.'
Quietly tells Scott 'I miss you.'
Defends the movement insisting people need to be up-front.
Does not deny his past closeted behavior though it's criticized.
Dismisses Scott's accusation of hypocrisy without defensiveness.
States that the movement needs people to be up-front and confrontational, showing awareness of leadership roles and movement dynamics.
Confronts Scott about fighting him and hypocrisy, evidencing confidence and directness.
Admits to family knowing his truth despite previous secrecy, showing some self-awareness and honesty.
Suggests that if families won't accept the kids for who they are, then those kids should lose those families, demonstrating principled but potentially rigid thinking.
Quietly admits to missing Scott, exposing a personal vulnerability that has been described as his 'Achilles heel,' which could be seen as a weakness impacting his effectiveness.
Walks away alone after Scott leaves, potentially indicating isolation or emotional challenges that might affect his capability.
Offers to help Dan craft a more acceptable proposal that doesn't displace kids.
Firmly refuses to back down or change his stance despite pressure.
Tells Dan he only needs one more vote and encourages him to convince others, maintaining a composed and rational tone.
Rips down a violent death threat letter and throws it away despite the fear and danger.
Documents the political and social backlash against gay rights carefully and stays informed about opposition movements like Anita Bryant's campaign.
Throws away a violent death threat letter tacked to his refrigerator, showing resilience and refusal to be intimidated.
Gives Cleve a bullhorn and encourages him to lead the march despite Cleve's nerves, showing trust and support.
Expresses uncertainty but looks Cleve in the eye and asks him to be the 'scary one' now, demonstrating sincere encouragement and belief in others.
Quickly organizes activists during an unfolding riot, delegates roles, and uses past experiences (e.g., getting Coors out of the bars) to equip others with tools like a bullhorn.
Formulates a strategic plan to prevent a riot by having Cleve march people to City Hall and playing peacemaker in public, aiming to gain political power.
Demonstrates self-awareness by acknowledging he won't always be present and empowering others to take leadership roles.
Shows confidence and clear communication in directing others amidst chaos and uncertainty.
Appears slightly unsure ('off Cleve, unsure') when instructing how to march people, which indicates some doubt.
Rushes to City Hall, straightens his tie to collect himself before facing the angry mob.
Pushes past police to greet the mob and speaks to recruit them, showing openness and sincerity.
Addresses the crowd passionately to recruit them for the fight against bigotry and to preserve democracy.
Encourages Cleve to speak sincerely from the heart rather than relying on note cards, showing trust and concern for authentic connection.
Expresses frustration over losing support and the lack of visibility, showing his investment in the cause rather than personal glory.
Shows impatience or critical tone towards Cleve celebrating the near-riot despite the bigger problem at hand.
Identifies a simple, relatable city issue (dog poop) as a political platform to attract voters, showing awareness of public concerns and populist appeal.
Uses humor and staged incident (stepping in dog poop) effectively during a press moment to draw attention to the issue and promote his message.
Watches and studies his own photo and announcement on the front page, preparing for a city supervisors' vote, indicating careful attention to public image and political process.
Celebrates the passing of the Gay Rights Ordinance with public enthusiasm and acknowledges the community's applause.
Approaches Mayor Moscone with a sincere and hopeful alliance offer, emphasizing mutual support between the gay community and the mayor.
Engages with Dan White in a non-hostile manner despite Dan's cold response, attempting to initiate dialogue.
Successfully sponsors and passes the San Francisco Gay Rights Ordinance, gaining significant press attention and public support.
Skillfully negotiates and forms an alliance with Mayor Moscone by offering a symbolic gesture (powder blue pen) and securing the mayor's public support.
Maintains confident and poised body language during high-pressure public moments, such as the press conference and signing of the ordinance.
Attempts to engage Dan White in conversation despite a cold, dismissive response, showing an effort to communicate but possibly underestimating Dan's attitude.

Dismisses Anne and Cleve's attempt to cut someone out but does not take immediate action, postponing the decision.
Uses self-deprecating humor to defuse tension and appear approachable.
Internal reaction to being part of the political 'Machine' shows some discomfort but no visible loss of composure.
Stays late after the gathering and braces himself for an approaching figure, indicating awareness and readiness.

Does not reject Dan's unusual and awkward hug, even though he stiffens, tolerates the uncomfortable interaction without hostility.
Expresses skepticism toward Dan's compliment, displaying some bluntness ('I doubt that').
Admits to painful personal history and struggles, showing vulnerability and honesty about closeted life and its impact on relationships.

Acknowledges threats of violence but chooses to speak to the crowd despite danger.
Gives an impassioned call for people to come out to their parents, friends, neighbors, and coworkers to break down myths and lies.
Despite receiving a death threat, he chooses to go on stage and deliver a powerful, confident speech to rally people, showing courage, leadership, and confidence under pressure.
Exhibits paranoia by scanning the crowd for threats, but uses this awareness to prepare himself mentally rather than freeze or avoid responsibility.
Delivers a speech affirming equality and constitutional rights against bigotry, promoting inclusiveness and tolerance.
Prepares to confront John Briggs with the support of police and press, extending his hand as a show of civility despite Briggs' discomfort.
Delivers an inspiring and well-articulated speech invoking foundational American principles to counter bigotry.
Immediately seizes the opportunity to involve the press to escalate their position against Briggs.
Organizes a public confrontation with Briggs involving key figures and media, showing strategic planning and confidence.
Respectfully challenges John Briggs to a public debate despite Briggs' hostility.
Appeals to Christian values emphasizing acceptance and love to counter Briggs' argument.
Challenges John Briggs to a public debate with the city's mayor and press as witnesses, showing confidence and strategic boldness.
Engages Briggs in a public debate, using moral and logical arguments to dismantle Briggs' statements and sway the audience.
Delivers a reasoned and sincere rebuttal to a homophobic claim on TV, using humor and logic to defuse prejudice.
Expresses genuine fear and concern about the impact of Proposition Six and openly shares pessimism, showing honesty and vulnerability.
Uses humor and logical reasoning during a TV appearance to effectively counter homophobic arguments, engaging and persuading the audience.
Expresses pessimism about beating Proposition Six but shifts to strategic organizing for future revolt, showing realistic appraisal but proactive planning.
Paces and acts decisively in his office while coordinating with supporters coming out in other cities, demonstrating leadership and purposeful action.
Refuses to use his fame for game shows now, prioritizing more important goals.
Responds calmly to Jack Lira's anger and accusations, expresses belief and support in him despite conflict.
Questions Jack if he is drunk during Jack's outburst, showing a direct and somewhat blunt approach.
Attempts to deescalate tension by offering to find Jack a job and acknowledging his capabilities.
Passively accepts Jack throwing an object and then calmly goes to get a broom to clean up.
Initiates a strategic media move by calling Briggs's office and offering control over audience and location, showing tactical planning.
Calmly deflects Jack's emotional outburst and prioritizes political goals over personal gain such as game shows.
Offers support and encouragement to Jack despite conflict, showing emotional intelligence and leadership.
Skillfully challenges opponent's flawed logic during debate, uses facts and rhetoric confidently.
Maintains composure and humor in face of hostile audience.
Laughs in disbelief at opponent's argument, showing confidence and command of the subject.
Challenges State Senator Briggs on his lust for power and the harm it causes to lives and careers.
Tries to maintain composure amid a hateful crowd in Orange County.
Responds warmly and with concern to Jack Lira, showing attentiveness and playfulness despite stressful circumstances.
Confronts State Senator Briggs boldly and articulately, exposing the moral failings behind Briggs' argument and appealing to the audience's sense of justice.
Attempts to maintain composure despite a hostile crowd in unfamiliar territory (Orange County), showing emotional control under pressure.

Asks Dan about his baby in a friendly manner.

Accuses Dan of trying to set him up and of political maneuvering.
